awd_titl_txt: IUSE/PFE:RED: Reinventing the Instructional and Departmental Enterprise (RIDE) to Advance the Professional Formation of Electrical and Computer Engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
Electrical and computer engineering (ECE) technologies have evolved from simple electronics and computing devices and tools to complex systems that profoundly change the world we live in. Designing these complex systems requires not only technical knowledge and skills but also new ways of thinking and the development of social, professional and ethical responsibility. Through the RIDE project, the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Iowa State University is involving students, faculty, engineers and others in collaborative, inquiry-driven processes to collectively and systematically transform the department and the engineers it trains. Students are not only learning about fundamental ECE technologies in core courses during their sophomore and junior years (middle years), but also the socio-technical context to go beyond the hardware and software toward responsible development. Students are expanding their analysis and design skills to create solutions that work for individuals and society. To accomplish these goals, faculty are reshaping core curricula using evidence-based pedagogical strategies and are working together to enhance their understanding and integration of these strategies in courses. This work is being done through new structures for collaboration and facilitated through departmental change processes. The project is expected to advance scholarly teaching and education research department-wide; serve as a model for ECE, computing and engineering departments across the country; enhance the capacity to conduct engineering education research at Iowa State; develop a diverse, socio-technical-minded ECE workforce; and broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in ECE, especially women, through inclusive learning experiences.

Through this project, the ECE department is undergoing a transformation to a more agile, less traditional organization able to respond to industry and society needs and sustain innovations. This transformation is being driven by the project's novel cross-functional, collaborative instructional model for course design and professional formation, called X-teams. X-teams are reshaping the core technical ECE curricula in the middle years through pedagogical approaches that (a) promote design thinking, systems thinking, professional skills such as leadership, and inclusion; (b) contextualize course concepts; and (c) stimulate creative, socio-technical-minded development of ECE technologies for future smart systems. X-teams are also serving as change agents for the rest of the department through communities of practice referred to as Y-circles. Y-circles, comprised of X-team members, faculty, staff, and undergraduate and graduate students in the department, are contributing to an organizational culture that fosters and sustains innovations in engineering education through an agile framework that blends several documented change theories, including collaborative transformation, crucial conversations, and essential tension. Y-circles are engaging in a process of discovery and inquiry to bridge the engineering education research-to-practice gap. Research studies are being conducted to answer questions to understand (1) how educators involved in X-teams use design thinking to create new pedagogical solutions; (2) how professional formation pedagogy in the middle years affects student professional ECE identity development as design thinkers; (3) how ECE students overcome barriers, make choices, and persist along their educational and career paths in the middle years; and (4) the effects of department structures, policies, and procedures on faculty attitudes, motivation and actions. These studies are informing and improving project activities, advancing knowledge, and supporting adaptation by others.

por.por_cntn:
Iowa State University?s RIDE project, Reinventing the Instructional and Departmental Enterprise (RIDE) to Advance the Professional Formation of Electrical and Computer Engineers (ECE), advanced the goals of the National Science Foundation?s Revolutionizing Engineering Departments (RED) program and Professional Formation of Engineers initiative.

The RIDE project?s course design research revealed that design thinking can enhance the practices of engineering faculty instructors both individually and collectively. By engaging in collaborative, facilitated design thinking experiences, faculty developed more student-centered and experimental mindsets. Faculty leveraged these experiences and mindsets to better understand student needs, develop novel course activities to address those needs, and engage in iterative cycles to improve those course activities. Engaging in these new practices and mindsets was challenged by both personal and contextual factors (e.g., prior course design practices, existing course and departmental structures). These challenges were mitigated by four key activities: (1) scaffolded use of design thinking tools (e.g., personas) that had been tailored to faculty needs; (2) repeated cycles of individual action and collaborative reflection; (3) opportunities to engage with different perspectives; and (4) envisioning the benefits of design thinking to teaching and learning practices in courses and the department. More research is needed to understand (1) how faculty in other contexts may engage in and be affected by similar experiences and (2) how newly developed mindsets and practices can be sustained. RIDE researchers also identified over one hundred course design heuristics that can support instructors in course design.

The project?s professional formation and identity research revealed that design thinking by students is a promising practice for developing engineering identity. It can encourage students to see themselves within engineering and make the engineering design process more accessible for a broad range of students. However, implementation of design thinking practices is an important element in engaging engineering students. Positive experiences of students are influenced by the qualities of assignments used by instructors and the guidance of student groups. Finally, design thinking practices used by students have possibilities for encouraging engineering identity in in-person classrooms and labs, however, those practices become more complicated when taken online, as seen during the COVID-19 pandemic. More research is needed in order to fully understand how design thinking may influence identity development in online space beyond the pandemic setting. RIDE researchers also studied other ways that engineering identity development may be influenced by the department, for example, how departmental documents and teaching assistants can help students see themselves as engineers.

The project?s research on faculty motivation found that support from the department chair was positively associated with the three basic psychological needs underlying motivation: competence, autonomy, and relatedness. These needs were positively associated with indicators of faculty well-being. Competence and relatedness fully mediated the relationships between chair support and each index of engineering faculty well-being. Results suggest that competence and relatedness may represent two salient tools through which university leadership can enhance engineering faculty well-being.

The project examined departmental change in four categories of curriculum and pedagogy, reflective teachers, policy, and shared vision. The project found evidence of change in each category. Faculty and academic advisers in the department were surveyed to determine perceptions of, perspectives on, and experiences with departmental change during the RIDE project. Respondents indicated that change strategies in every category were relevant to department goals and/or were important to them individually. However, more efforts are needed to increase the awareness of change in the department and sharing of teaching knowledge and practices.

As a broader impact, the RIDE project engaged ECE departments nationally through the NSF RED Consortium, the ECE Department Heads Association, the American Society for Engineering Education ECE Division, the IEEE Frontiers in Education Conference, and ECE department seminars.  In addition, the RIDE project contributed to advancing engineering education research as a strategic research area and future graduate program at Iowa State University.
